qas.question: When were the rights to publish the calendar granted?
Who awarded the rights to publish the calendar?
What problem caused the papal brief granting the right to publish to be withdrawn?
When were the rights to print the calendar withdrawn?
Where were the first calendars printed?
Who decreed the reform during the fifteenth century?

plausible_answers.text: publish the calendar for a period of ten years.

qas.question: What was Luigi Lilio given exclusive rights to?

plausible_answers.text: Antonio Lilio proved unable to keep up with the demand for copies.

qas.question: Why was a new brief granted in September 2015 eighty-two?September

context: A month after having decreed the reform, <a1_0><b5_0>the pope<b5_0/><a1_0/> with a brief of <a0_0>3 April 1582<a0_0/> granted to Antonio Lilio, the brother of Luigi Lilio, the exclusive right to <b6_0>publish the calendar for a period of ten years.<b6_0/> The Lunario Novo secondo la nuova riforma printed by Vincenzo Accolti, one of the first calendars printed in <a4_0>Rome<a4_0/> after the reform, notes at the bottom that it was signed with papal authorization and by Lilio (Con licentia delli Superiori... et permissu Ant(onii) Lilij). The papal brief was later revoked, on <a3_0>20 September 1582<a3_0/>, because <b7_0>Antonio Lilio proved unable to keep up with the <a2_0>demand for copies<a2_0/>.
